SMC219Y1-Y-20205.courseDescription: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
SMC219Y1-Y-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
SMC219Y1-Y-20205.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

SMC228H1-F-20205.courseDescription: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.
SMC228H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, synchronous course. Each online “live” session (Monday and Wednesday 10am to 1pm) is normally divided into three parts: (a) a lecture, to introduce the key concepts, mostly from weekly readings; (b) a case study-based presentation and discussion, including questions and clarifications about lecture; and (c) an active learning activity, including online tutorials and learning exercises. Part (a) lecture will be recorded and available to students following each session. Lecture slides and other learning materials, such as weekly readings, case studies, and digital handouts will be posted on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Zoom for all online sessions and Quercus for readings, assignments, and tests.

SMC229H1-S-20205.courseDescription: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.
SMC229H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. A pair of two-hour lectures will be made available each week. Students will also have the opportunity for synchronous online discussion of the lectures and course readings on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3-4pm. All students will need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and to broadcast audio and video to their fellow classmates.

SMC314H1-S-20205.courseDescription: A deeper examination of key cases in the development of media, such as the invention of movable type, the mechanization of the printing press, standardization of call number systems (Dewey, LC, etc.), the advent of radio, television and internet. Topics vary from year to year, according to the instructor.
SMC314H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-2hr online videos and/or slides/week asynchronously. Students will have opportunity for a few optional synchronous online webinar meetings (Wednesdays, 2-4pm) with Professor to ask questions and receive clarification about course content and assignments. Students need access to Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

LEC-9901.meetingStatusNotes:
Course Added: April 8, 2020.
Students will require access to the internet to stream lectures and submit coursework.
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions

SMC316H1-F-20205.courseDescription: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.
SMC316H1-F-20205.prerequisite: Enrolment priority for students enrolled in a Book and Media Studies program
SMC316H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).”

SMC380H1-F-20205.courseDescription: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC380H1-F-20205.prerequisite: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
SMC380H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Program Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.

SMC465H1-F-20205.courseDescription: An advanced seminar on McLuhan's theory of technology, perception, and social media.
SMC465H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Thursday 10-12am) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content; virtual office hours will also be available by appointment. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
